Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery vessel, probably a lekanis lid; underside has many bands and lines fired red; exterior: rays at centre; outside, black-figure frieze of female figures running to right: from left, part of face with traces of added white, hair, and white arm remaining, looking back; central figure wearing pinned and belted peplos, lower body missing, with white on arms and face and traces of added red on peplos and white dotted belt; incised maeander on paryphe; at right, perhaps tail of Triton or Nereus.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.113a.1899. The sherd is also published in Beazley (1956) Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters, p. 89, no. 3, where it is attributed to the Burgon Group. The remains to right Beazley interprets as part of Triton's tail, while the triangular mark on the border may have belonged to a dolphin.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 340, no. B410)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 39, pl. XX, no. 5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.2105)
